title: Compound Sentences — Using But, Or, and So
description: Students deepen their understanding of compound sentences by focusing on conjunctions that show contrast (but/yet), choice (or), and result (so/for). They learn to choose the most precise conjunction for the relationship between ideas.
instructions:
1. Review compound sentences and FANBOYS.
2. Focus on BUT: shows contrast — 'I wanted ice cream, BUT the store was closed.'
3. Focus on OR: shows choice — 'We can walk, OR we can ride bikes.'
4. Focus on SO: shows result — 'It started raining, SO we went inside.'
5. Practice choosing the best conjunction for sentence pairs.
6. Revise choppy paragraphs by combining sentences.
7. Write an original paragraph using all three conjunctions.

items: Conjunction cards: but, or, so, yet, for
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare sentence pairs where the relationship is clear: some showing contrast, some showing choice, some showing cause/effect. Write a short paragraph with only simple sentences for the revision exercise.

slides.text: Last week we learned to join sentences with conjunctions. Today we become more PRECISE. Different conjunctions show different relationships. BUT shows CONTRAST: 'The pizza was cold, BUT it was still delicious.' The two ideas oppose each other.

OR shows CHOICE: 'You can have the red cup, OR you can have the blue one.' The reader must pick between two options. SO shows RESULT: 'The dog was hungry, SO he ate his dinner quickly.' The second part HAPPENED BECAUSE of the first part.

Choosing the right conjunction matters! Listen: 'It was snowing, AND we went sledding' vs. 'It was snowing, SO we went sledding.' Both work, but SO is more precise because it shows that the snowing CAUSED the sledding. Good writers choose conjunctions carefully.

Let us revise a choppy paragraph: 'The knight put on his armor. He climbed on his horse. He rode to the castle. The gate was locked. He could not enter.' Revised: 'The knight put on his armor AND climbed on his horse, SO he could ride to the castle, BUT the gate was locked, SO he could not enter.' Much smoother!

slides.prompt: Choose the best conjunction (and, but, or, so) for each pair: 1) 'She studied hard' + 'she passed the test.' 2) 'The movie was long' + 'it was never boring.' 3) 'We can go swimming' + 'we can go hiking.' 4) 'He forgot his lunch' + 'he was hungry all day.' Then write an original paragraph about a medieval adventure using at least one AND, one BUT, one OR, and one SO.

slides.text: Choosing the right conjunction is like choosing the right tool — it makes the job precise. AND adds, BUT contrasts, OR offers choices, SO shows results. When you revise your writing, look for places where a better conjunction could make your meaning clearer.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child choose the most appropriate conjunction for a given relationship and use but, or, and so correctly in compound sentences?

parent_notes: This lesson refines the compound sentence skill from last week. The key insight is that conjunctions carry meaning — they are not interchangeable. Children often overuse 'and' because it is safe; encouraging 'but,' 'or,' and 'so' adds sophistication. The paragraph revision exercise shows the practical value of compound sentences. In everyday conversation, occasionally ask: 'Did that happen BECAUSE of the first thing (so), or was it different from what you expected (but)?' This builds logical thinking alongside language skills.

title: Fractions — Comparing and Ordering with Unlike Denominators
description: Students learn to compare fractions with different denominators using fraction circle insets. They discover that comparing fractions requires either the same denominator or a visual comparison, and they order fractions from least to greatest.
instructions:
1. Review comparing fractions with like denominators.
2. Present a new challenge: Which is bigger, 1/3 or 1/4?
3. Use fraction circles to compare physically.
4. Extend: Which is bigger, 2/3 or 3/4?
5. Discuss: Why cannot we just compare numerators when denominators are different?
6. Practice ordering sets of fractions using the circles.
7. Record comparisons in math journal.

slides.heading: Comparing Fractions
slides.subheading: Which Is Bigger When Denominators Differ?

items: Montessori fraction circle insets (halves through tenths)
Comparison symbol cards: < (less than), > (greater than), = (equal to)
slides.setup_instructions: Set out all fraction circle insets. Have comparison symbols visible and explained. Prepare sets of fractions to compare and order. The journal should have a page titled 'Comparing Fractions.'

slides.text: Comparing 1/4 and 3/4 is easy — same denominator, just compare numerators: 3/4 is bigger. But what about 1/3 and 1/4? Different denominators! We cannot just compare numbers. Let us use the fraction circles to SEE which is bigger.

Take 1 third-piece and 1 fourth-piece. Place them side by side. Which is bigger? 1/3 is bigger than 1/4! This makes sense: when you cut a pie into 3 pieces, each piece is bigger than when you cut the same pie into 4 pieces. More pieces = smaller pieces!

Harder one: Which is bigger, 2/3 or 3/4? Take 2 third-pieces and 3 fourth-pieces. Lay them in their circles. 3/4 is just slightly bigger! We can write: 2/3 < 3/4 (two-thirds is less than three-fourths). The fraction circles let us see what numbers alone might confuse us.

Here is a useful trick for unit fractions (fractions with 1 on top): the BIGGER the denominator, the SMALLER the fraction! 1/2 > 1/3 > 1/4 > 1/5 > 1/6 > 1/8 > 1/10. Think about it: cutting a pizza into 10 pieces gives you much smaller slices than cutting it into 2 pieces!

slides.prompt: Use fraction circles to compare. Write <, >, or = between each pair: 1) 1/2 ___ 1/3, 2) 2/4 ___ 1/2, 3) 2/3 ___ 1/2, 4) 3/4 ___ 2/3, 5) 1/4 ___ 1/6. Then put these fractions in order from SMALLEST to LARGEST: 1/2, 1/4, 3/4, 1/3. Draw the fraction circles for your ordering to prove your answer is correct.

slides.text: Comparing fractions with different denominators is tricky with numbers alone, but the fraction circles make it visible! Remember: for fractions with 1 on top, bigger denominators mean smaller fractions. For other fractions, use the circles to compare visually. Later, you will learn to use common denominators — but for now, the circles are your best tool!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child compare fractions with unlike denominators using fraction circles and order a set of 4 fractions from least to greatest?

parent_notes: Comparing unlike fractions is conceptually challenging because our number sense (bigger number = bigger value) breaks down with denominators. The fraction circles make this concrete. The rule 'bigger denominator = smaller piece' applies only to unit fractions (1/something). For non-unit fractions, visual comparison with circles is the appropriate method at this level. Do not introduce cross-multiplication or common denominator procedures yet — the concrete understanding must come first. Let the child hold and compare pieces as long as they need.

title: The Middle Ages — Castles: Fortresses and Homes
description: Students explore medieval castles as both military fortresses and living spaces. They learn about castle architecture: moats, drawbridges, walls, towers, keeps, and great halls, understanding how each feature served defensive and domestic purposes.
instructions:
1. Show images and diagrams of medieval castles.
2. Explain why castles were built: protection from enemies.
3. Tour the castle features: moat, drawbridge, curtain wall, towers, keep.
4. Describe daily life inside: great hall for feasts, chapel, kitchen, well.
5. Discuss castle evolution: from wood to stone, from simple to complex.
6. The child designs their own castle with defensive features.
7. Record in history journal.
materials_needed: Images and diagrams of medieval castles

slides.heading: Medieval Castles
slides.subheading: Fortresses and Homes of the Middle Ages

items: Photographs and cutaway diagrams of medieval castles
Colored pencils and ruler for castle design
slides.setup_instructions: Display several castle images including cutaway diagrams showing internal rooms. Have a labeled diagram of castle parts visible. Famous examples: Dover Castle, Warwick Castle, Krak des Chevaliers.

slides.text: In the dangerous Middle Ages, powerful lords needed protection. They built CASTLES — massive stone fortresses that served as military bases AND homes. The first castles (around 900 AD) were simple wooden towers on hills called 'motte and bailey' castles. Over centuries, they evolved into the massive stone fortresses we see in movies!

Every castle feature was designed for DEFENSE. The MOAT (water-filled ditch) prevented enemies from reaching the walls. The DRAWBRIDGE could be raised to block entry. CURTAIN WALLS were thick stone walls (up to 20 feet thick!). TOWERS gave archers high positions to shoot down at attackers. ARROW SLITS were narrow windows — you could shoot out, but enemies could not shoot in.

The heart of the castle was the KEEP — the tallest, strongest tower where the lord's family lived. If all other defenses fell, they retreated to the keep for a last stand. Inside the castle were the GREAT HALL (for feasts, meetings, and justice), the CHAPEL, kitchens, storerooms, a WELL for water, and sleeping quarters.

Castle life was not comfortable by modern standards! Castles were cold and drafty — tapestries hung on walls helped keep warmth in. Toilets (called garderobes) were holes in the wall that emptied into the moat! But the great hall could be magnificent: roaring fireplaces, long tables for feasts, music, and storytelling.

slides.prompt: Design your own medieval castle! Draw a bird's-eye view (from above) AND a side view. Include and label these defensive features: moat, drawbridge, curtain wall with towers, keep, arrow slits, and a gatehouse. Add living spaces: great hall, chapel, kitchen, and well. In your journal, write a paragraph explaining how THREE features protect the castle from attack.

slides.text: Medieval castles are some of the most impressive structures ever built. They combined engineering, military strategy, and architecture into one building. Many still stand today, 800-1,000 years later! Next time, we will explore who lived in and around castles and what daily life was like.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child label at least 6 castle features and explain the defensive purpose of 3 of them?

parent_notes: Castles are universally fascinating for children. The combination of military strategy and daily life makes them rich for learning. If possible, find a virtual castle tour online (many UK castles offer these). Building a model castle from cardboard boxes is an excellent extended project that reinforces the lesson. Connect to the feudal system: the lord lived in the castle, knights defended it, peasants farmed the surrounding land. The evolution from wooden to stone castles parallels the development of siege weapons — each innovation prompted a counter-innovation.

title: South America — The Amazon Rainforest Ecosystem
description: Students take a deep dive into the Amazon Rainforest, the world's largest tropical rainforest. They learn about its layers (emergent, canopy, understory, forest floor), biodiversity, indigenous peoples, and why it is called the 'lungs of the Earth.'
instructions:
1. Locate the Amazon Rainforest on the map — it spans 9 countries.
2. Explain the four layers of the rainforest.
3. Discuss biodiversity: more species than any other ecosystem.
4. Introduce indigenous peoples who live in the Amazon.
5. Explain the rainforest's role in producing oxygen and absorbing carbon.
6. Discuss threats: deforestation, climate change.
7. The child creates a layered diagram of the rainforest.

items: Map showing the Amazon Basin across South America
Images of rainforest layers and animals
Large drawing paper for layered diagram
slides.setup_instructions: Display the map showing the Amazon's extent across 9 countries. Gather images of each rainforest layer with representative animals. Have large paper ready for the cross-section diagram.

slides.text: The Amazon Rainforest covers 2.1 million square miles — it is larger than the entire country of India! It spans 9 countries, with most in Brazil. The Amazon River runs through it, carrying one-fifth of all the world's river water. This is the most biodiverse place on Earth — scientists discover new species there every single day.

The rainforest has FOUR LAYERS. EMERGENT LAYER (top, 200+ feet): the tallest trees poke above the canopy. Eagles and butterflies live here. CANOPY (60-130 feet): a thick roof of branches and leaves where most animals live — monkeys, toucans, sloths, tree frogs. 70-80% of rainforest life is in the canopy!

UNDERSTORY (below canopy): dimmer, with smaller trees and shrubs. Jaguars, snakes, and insects thrive here. FOREST FLOOR (ground): very dark — only 2% of sunlight reaches the ground! Decomposers (fungi, insects, bacteria) break down fallen leaves and return nutrients to the soil. Giant anteaters and tapirs roam here.

The Amazon is called the 'Lungs of the Earth' because its trees absorb enormous amounts of carbon dioxide and release oxygen. Indigenous peoples have lived in and protected the Amazon for thousands of years. Today, deforestation (cutting down trees for farming and ranching) threatens this irreplaceable ecosystem.

slides.prompt: Create a cross-section diagram of the Amazon Rainforest showing all four layers. Label each layer with its name and height. Draw at least 2 animals in each layer. Color the diagram with appropriate greens (darker at bottom, lighter at top). In your journal, write: Why is the Amazon called the 'Lungs of the Earth'? Why should we protect it? Name 3 things that make the Amazon unique.

slides.text: The Amazon Rainforest is one of Earth's greatest treasures — it produces oxygen, stores carbon, holds millions of species, and is home to indigenous peoples. Protecting it is one of the most important challenges facing our world. Every person can help by learning about it, talking about it, and making choices that support rainforest conservation.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name and describe the four rainforest layers, explain why the Amazon matters for the whole planet, and identify threats to the rainforest?

parent_notes: The Amazon unit combines geography, biology, ecology, and social studies. The four-layer model is an excellent organizing framework. If your child is passionate about animals, each layer offers rich research possibilities. The indigenous peoples discussion should be respectful and acknowledge that these communities have deep knowledge and rights to their land. The conservation message is important but should be balanced — focus on solutions and empowerment rather than despair. Consider watching age-appropriate Amazon documentaries to bring this lesson to life.

title: Read Aloud — Ramona Quimby, Age 8, Chapters 1-3
description: Begin Beverly Cleary's 'Ramona Quimby, Age 8,' meeting the spirited Ramona as she starts third grade. Students discuss realistic fiction, character voice, and the experience of starting something new.
instructions:
1. Introduce Beverly Cleary and the Ramona series.
2. Read chapters 1-3 aloud.
3. Discuss: How is Ramona different from James (previous book)?
4. Identify realistic fiction: stories that could happen in real life.
5. Discuss Ramona's feelings about starting third grade.
6. Connect to the child's own experiences of starting something new.
7. The child writes about a time they started something new.
materials_needed: Ramona Quimby, Age 8 by Beverly Cleary

slides.heading: Ramona Quimby, Age 8
slides.subheading: Chapters 1-3: The First Day of School

items: Ramona Quimby, Age 8 by Beverly Cleary
slides.setup_instructions: This is a very different book from James and the Giant Peach — realistic fiction instead of fantasy. Read with a natural, conversational tone. Ramona's internal thoughts are key — voice them as a third-grader would think.

slides.text: After our fantastical adventure with James and a giant peach, we are entering the REAL world with Ramona Quimby! Beverly Cleary wrote stories about ordinary kids with ordinary problems — but she made them funny, touching, and real. Ramona is 8, starting third grade, and full of big feelings and strong opinions.

This is REALISTIC FICTION — stories that could really happen. There are no magic crystals or giant insects, but there IS a girl trying to be brave on her first day at a new school, dealing with annoying classmates, and worrying about her family. Realistic fiction helps us understand ourselves and others.

As we read, notice Ramona's VOICE — the way she thinks and talks. She is honest (sometimes too honest!), determined, and emotional. She tries hard to be good but things do not always go as planned. Have you ever felt that way? Cleary captures childhood feelings perfectly.

slides.prompt: In your reading journal, create a character profile for Ramona. List her age, family members, personality traits (at least 4), and what worries her. Then write about a time YOU started something new (new school, new class, new activity). How did you feel? What happened? Use at least 3 adjectives and 2 adverbs to describe your experience.

slides.text: Ramona is a character millions of children have loved for over 40 years because she is SO REAL. Everyone has felt what Ramona feels — nervous, embarrassed, proud, frustrated, happy. That is the power of realistic fiction: it shows us we are not alone in our feelings.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child describe Ramona's character, explain what realistic fiction is, and connect the story to their own experiences?

parent_notes: Ramona Quimby, Age 8 is a wonderful bridge from fantasy to realistic fiction. Beverly Cleary's genius is capturing the inner life of children with humor and respect. Ramona's problems — being embarrassed, wanting approval, dealing with siblings — are universal. This book naturally sparks conversations about feelings, family, and school. If your child says 'this is boring compared to James,' give it time — Cleary's charm is in the relatable details, not the dramatic plot. Many children end up loving Ramona more because she feels real.

title: Journal Writing — Personal Narratives
description: Students learn to write personal narratives: true stories from their own lives. They practice using a clear beginning, middle, and end structure, incorporating dialogue, adjectives, adverbs, and compound sentences.
instructions:
1. Discuss personal narratives: true stories about YOUR life.
2. Model the structure: beginning (set the scene), middle (what happened), end (how it resolved/what you learned).
3. Brainstorm story ideas from the child's life.
4. The child chooses one experience and maps it out.
5. Write a first draft using descriptive language.
6. Add dialogue to make characters come alive.
7. Revise for grammar and spelling.

items: Language journal and pencil with eraser
Story planning graphic organizer (beginning, middle, end)
List of writing skills to include: adjectives, adverbs, compound sentences, dialogue
slides.setup_instructions: Create a simple graphic organizer with three boxes: Beginning (Who? Where? When?), Middle (What happened? The problem or exciting part), End (How did it end? What did you learn?). Have skill reminders visible.

slides.text: A PERSONAL NARRATIVE is a true story from your life. It is not just 'what I did today' — it is a story with a BEGINNING (setting the scene), a MIDDLE (something interesting or challenging happened), and an END (how it worked out and what you learned or felt). Your life is full of stories worth telling!

The BEGINNING hooks the reader. Instead of 'One day I went to the park,' try: 'The autumn leaves crunched under my boots as I raced toward the biggest slide in the park.' Use adjectives and adverbs to paint the scene. Make the reader feel like they are THERE.

The MIDDLE is where the action happens. Include DIALOGUE — the actual words people said. Use quotation marks: Mom called, "Be careful up there!" BUT I was already climbing. Dialogue makes your story come alive. Use compound sentences to keep the pace flowing.

The END resolves the story and shares what you felt or learned. 'As I slid down, the wind in my face felt like flying. I had been scared, BUT I did it anyway. Sometimes the scariest things are the most fun.' A strong ending stays with the reader.

slides.prompt: Choose a true story from your life: a time you were brave, embarrassed, surprised, proud, or learned something important. Use the graphic organizer to plan your beginning, middle, and end. Write at least 3 paragraphs. Include: 4+ adjectives, 2+ adverbs, 1+ compound sentence, and at least 2 lines of dialogue. Read it aloud when finished — does it sound like a real story?

slides.text: Everyone has stories worth sharing. Personal narratives let you preserve your memories and share your experiences with others. The more you practice, the better your stories become. Keep a list of story ideas in your journal — when something interesting, funny, or meaningful happens, write it down before you forget!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child write a personal narrative with a clear beginning, middle, and end, incorporating dialogue and descriptive language?

parent_notes: Personal narrative writing is one of the most important writing skills for this age. Children write best about what they know and feel. If your child struggles to choose a topic, suggest categories: a time I was scared, my best day ever, the funniest thing that happened to me, a time I tried something new. The graphic organizer prevents the common problem of 'and then... and then... and then...' rambling. Celebrate the story itself — technical corrections can come in revision. Consider creating a family story collection where everyone contributes personal narratives.

title: Measurement — Estimating and Measuring in Inches and Centimeters
description: Students practice measurement skills by estimating and measuring objects around the home or classroom. They develop benchmark references (finger width = 1 cm, thumb width = 1 inch) and practice measuring to the nearest half-inch.
instructions:
1. Review proper ruler use from last week.
2. Establish benchmarks: 1 cm is about a fingernail width, 1 inch is about a thumb width.
3. Practice estimating with benchmarks before measuring.
4. Introduce half-inch measurements: the halfway mark between inches.
5. Measure objects to the nearest half-inch.
6. Create a measurement scavenger hunt.
7. Record all measurements in a chart.

slides.heading: Measurement Practice
slides.subheading: Estimating with Benchmarks and Measuring to Half-Inches

items: Rulers showing both inches (with half-inch marks) and centimeters
Various objects: hand, foot, arm, spoon, book, pencil case, remote control, shoe
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a scavenger hunt list: 'Find something about 3 inches long, something about 15 cm long, something about 1 foot long, etc.' Have rulers ready and journal open to a measurement chart.

slides.text: Good measurers can ESTIMATE before they measure. How? Use BENCHMARKS — measurements you carry with you! Your fingernail width is about 1 centimeter. Your thumb width is about 1 inch. The distance from your nose to your fingertip (arm stretched out) is about 1 yard or 1 meter. These benchmarks let you estimate anywhere!

How long is this spoon? Use your thumb benchmark: about 5 thumb-widths, so approximately 5 inches. Now measure with the ruler: 5 and a half inches! Your estimate was close! The more you practice estimating, the more accurate you become.

Let us learn HALF-INCH measurements. Look at the ruler between the 3-inch and 4-inch marks. See the medium-length mark in the middle? That is 3 and one-half inches, written as 3 1/2 inches. If an object ends between a whole inch and the half-mark, round to the nearest half.

slides.prompt: Measurement Scavenger Hunt! Find and measure: 1) Something about 2 inches long, 2) Something about 10 cm long, 3) Something about 6 inches long, 4) Something about 20 cm long, 5) The longest thing you can find in the room, 6) The shortest thing you can find. For each: estimate first, then measure in BOTH inches and centimeters. Record in your chart. How close were your estimates?

slides.text: You are becoming a measurement expert! Benchmarks help you estimate quickly, and careful ruler use gives you exact measurements. In the real world, estimation is often just as useful as exact measurement — builders, cooks, and scientists estimate all the time. Keep practicing, and your estimates will get amazingly close!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child use benchmarks to estimate within 1 inch of actual measurement and measure to the nearest half-inch?

parent_notes: Measurement becomes meaningful through practice and real-world application. The benchmarks (finger = cm, thumb = inch, arm span = yard) give children portable measurement tools they always have with them. The scavenger hunt makes measurement a game. Accuracy to the nearest half-inch is appropriate for this age; measuring to quarter-inches comes later. Cooking is the best ongoing measurement practice: 'measure 1/2 cup,' 'cut 3-inch pieces.' Consider having the child measure ingredients for dinner as homework!

title: Simple Machines in Action — Compound Machines and Engineering
description: Students explore how simple machines combine to create compound machines. They analyze everyday objects (scissors, bicycles, wheelbarrows) to identify the simple machines within them and design their own compound machine to solve a problem.
instructions:
1. Review all six simple machines.
2. Define compound machine: a device made of two or more simple machines.
3. Analyze a pair of scissors: lever + wedge.
4. Analyze a wheelbarrow: lever + wheel and axle.
5. Analyze a bicycle: wheel and axle + lever + pulley (chain).
6. The child identifies simple machines in 5 household items.
7. Design a compound machine to solve a specific problem.
8. Record in science journal.

slides.heading: Compound Machines
slides.subheading: Combining Simple Machines to Solve Problems

items: Images of a wheelbarrow, bicycle, and other compound machines
Various household tools: can opener, broom, stapler, hole punch
Science journal, pencil, and colored pencils for design
slides.setup_instructions: Gather household tools for analysis. Have the 6 simple machines reference page visible. Prepare a 'problem to solve' for the design challenge (e.g., 'How could you lift a heavy box to a high shelf?').

slides.text: You know all 6 simple machines: lever, inclined plane, pulley, wheel and axle, wedge, and screw. But most tools you use every day are NOT single simple machines — they are COMPOUND MACHINES: combinations of two or more simple machines working together!

Let us analyze SCISSORS. The handles and blades pivot on a pin — that is a LEVER (actually two levers joined at the fulcrum). The blades have sharp edges — that is a WEDGE. So scissors = lever + wedge! A can opener has a lever (handle), a wedge (cutting edge), AND a wheel and axle (turning knob) — three simple machines!

A BICYCLE is a compound machine masterpiece! Wheels and axles (the wheels), levers (brake handles, pedals), a pulley system (chain and gears), and screws (bolts holding it together). Engineers combined simple machines to create one of the most efficient transportation devices ever invented!

Now YOU become an engineer! Engineers solve problems by combining simple machines in creative ways. Your challenge: design a machine to solve a specific problem. Think about what forces are needed and which simple machines could provide them.

slides.prompt: First, analyze 3 household tools: for each one, list the simple machines you can identify. Then tackle the design challenge: Design a compound machine that could help someone carry heavy groceries from a car to a second-floor apartment. Draw your design, label every simple machine in it, and explain how each part helps. Be creative — there is no wrong answer in engineering!

slides.text: Every machine in the world, from a simple nutcracker to a space shuttle, is built from combinations of six simple machines. Engineers are people who understand these building blocks and combine them creatively to solve problems. You are thinking like an engineer when you analyze and design compound machines!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify simple machines within compound machines and design a compound machine using at least 3 simple machines?

parent_notes: This lesson ties together the entire simple machines unit. The analysis activity (finding simple machines in household tools) can extend throughout the week as a fun ongoing game. The design challenge develops engineering thinking — there is no single right answer, which teaches creative problem-solving. If your child enjoys this, look into simple engineering kits (LEGO Technic, K'NEX simple machines) that let them build working compound machines. This unit naturally leads to conversations about careers in engineering and design.

title: Recorder — Adding Notes D and E, Playing 'Mary Had a Little Lamb'
description: Students add two new notes to their recorder repertoire: D (high) and E. They review B, A, and G, then learn to play 'Mary Had a Little Lamb' and 'Merrily We Roll Along,' building finger coordination and reading simple notation.
instructions:
1. Review B, A, and G with 'Hot Cross Buns.'
2. Teach high D: thumb + fingers 1-2-3 + right hand finger 4.
3. Teach high E: thumb + fingers 1-2.
4. Practice moving between all five notes.
5. Learn 'Mary Had a Little Lamb': E-D-C... wait, we need C! Use B instead for a simplified version: B-A-G-A-B-B-B.
6. Practice slowly, then build tempo.
7. Try 'Merrily We Roll Along': same notes as Mary, different rhythm.
materials_needed: Fingering chart with B, A, G, D, E

slides.heading: Recorder Melodies
slides.subheading: New Notes: D and E, Plus New Songs

items: Updated fingering chart showing B, A, G, D, and E
slides.setup_instructions: Review B, A, G fingerings. Add D and E to the fingering chart. Write out 'Mary Had a Little Lamb' and 'Hot Cross Buns' in letter notation large enough to read while playing.

slides.text: Let us warm up with B, A, G — play 'Hot Cross Buns' twice through. Good! Now we add two new notes. Note D: just like G (thumb + fingers 1-2-3) BUT add your RIGHT hand pointer finger (finger 4) on the next hole. Blow gently: 'too.' Lower than G! Note E: keep thumb and fingers 1-2 (same as A) — this gives us high E.

Wait, let me correct that. For THIS simplified version, we will use the notes we know best. Here is 'Mary Had a Little Lamb' using B, A, G: B-A-G-A, B-B-B (rest), A-A-A (rest), B-B-B (rest), B-A-G-A, B-B-B-B, A-A-B-A, G. Play each note clearly with a 'too' tongue.

The trick with new songs is to learn them SLOWLY first. Play each note, stop, think about the next note, play it. When you can play it slowly without mistakes, gradually speed up. Musicians call this 'practicing at tempo' — starting slow and building speed. Never practice mistakes — slow down until you get it right!

slides.prompt: Practice these exercises: 1) Play B-A-G-A-B going down and back up, 5 times smoothly. 2) Play 'Hot Cross Buns' from memory. 3) Play 'Mary Had a Little Lamb' at least 5 times, starting slowly. In your music journal, write out 'Mary Had a Little Lamb' in letter notation from memory. Challenge: Can you figure out another simple song by ear using B, A, and G?

slides.text: You now have a repertoire — multiple songs you can play! A repertoire grows over time as you learn more notes and songs. Practice each song every day for 5 minutes. Soon your fingers will move automatically and you can focus on making beautiful music rather than finding the right notes.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child play 'Hot Cross Buns' and 'Mary Had a Little Lamb' on the recorder with clear notes at a slow, steady tempo?

parent_notes: The second recorder lesson builds on the first. The simplified versions using B, A, G keep things manageable while building confidence. The key teaching point is 'slow practice' — musicians at every level use this technique. If the child rushes and makes mistakes, encourage them to slow down rather than push through. Tone quality improves with gentle, steady air (not blowing harder). Short daily practice (5-10 minutes) is far more effective than one long weekly session. Consider learning alongside your child — it is more fun together!

title: Cooking — Bread Making (Simple Flatbread)
description: Students learn the science and art of bread making by preparing a simple flatbread. They measure ingredients, mix dough, knead, shape, and cook flatbreads, learning about how flour, water, and heat create one of the world's oldest foods.
instructions:
1. Discuss the history of bread: one of humanity's oldest foods.
2. Read and review the recipe.
3. Measure all dry ingredients.
4. Mix and knead the dough.
5. Divide into portions and shape into flat rounds.
6. Cook on a hot skillet or griddle.
7. Eat and enjoy with butter or honey.
8. Clean up completely.

slides.heading: Bread Making
slides.subheading: Simple Flatbread — The World's Oldest Food

items: 2 tablespoons vegetable oil or olive oil
Mixing bowl, skillet or griddle, rolling pin
slides.setup_instructions: Gather all ingredients and tools. The child measures everything. This recipe makes 6-8 flatbreads. An adult should handle the hot skillet. The child does mixing, kneading, shaping, and can flip with supervision.

slides.text: Bread is one of humanity's OLDEST foods — people have been making it for at least 14,000 years! Ancient Egyptians, medieval monks, and people in every culture on Earth have made bread. Today we make FLATBREAD — the simplest, most ancient form. All you need is flour, water, salt, and heat.

Measure carefully: 2 cups flour, 1/2 teaspoon salt, 1 teaspoon baking powder. Mix the dry ingredients in the bowl. Make a well (hole) in the center. Pour in 3/4 cup warm water and 2 tablespoons oil. Mix with a fork until a shaggy dough forms.

Now KNEAD the dough. Dump it on a floured surface. Push the dough away from you with the heel of your hand, fold it back, turn it quarter turn, and push again. Repeat for 3-5 minutes until smooth and elastic. Kneading develops GLUTEN — the protein that makes bread chewy and holds it together!

Divide the dough into 6-8 balls. Roll each ball flat with the rolling pin — about 1/4 inch thick. Cook on a hot, lightly oiled skillet for 2-3 minutes per side until golden brown spots appear and it puffs up slightly. The HEAT causes the baking powder to release gas, which makes tiny bubbles — that is why it puffs!

slides.prompt: While the flatbreads cook, write the recipe in your own words in a recipe journal. Include ingredients, steps, and any tips you discovered. Draw a picture of your flatbread. Taste it plain, then with butter, honey, or jam. Rate it! Answer: How does this flatbread compare to store-bought bread? What is different?

slides.text: You just made bread from scratch — the same basic process humans have used for thousands of years! Bread connects us to every culture and every era of human history. Medieval monks made bread in their monasteries. Ancient Greeks ate flatbread with olive oil. You are part of that tradition!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child follow the recipe independently (with stove supervision), explain what kneading does, and describe why bread is historically important?

parent_notes: Bread making is deeply satisfying and connects to history, science (gluten development, gas expansion), math (measurement), and culture. This simple flatbread recipe requires no yeast or rising time, making it manageable in one session. Let the child do ALL the measuring and mixing; stove work needs supervision. If you have time, try a yeast bread on another day — watching dough rise is magical. Connect to the medieval monks lesson: monasteries were famous for their bread. Flatbreads exist in nearly every culture: naan, tortilla, pita, roti, lavash.

title: Adverbs in Writing — Strengthening Sentences
description: Students practice using adverbs strategically in their writing to make sentences more vivid and precise. They learn that while adverbs add detail, strong verbs sometimes work better, and they revise sentences using both strategies.
instructions:
1. Review adverb types: how, when, where.
2. Show the power of adverbs: 'She spoke' vs. 'She spoke softly.'
3. But also show: sometimes a STRONG VERB is better than verb + adverb.
4. Compare: 'She spoke softly' vs. 'She whispered.' Both work!
5. Practice choosing between adverbs and strong verbs.
6. Revise a paragraph to improve it with adverbs AND strong verbs.
7. Write original sentences using both techniques.

slides.heading: Adverbs in Writing
slides.subheading: When to Use Them and When a Strong Verb Works Better

items: Strong verb list: whisper, shout, dash, creep, gobble, sip, glance, stare, soar, trudge
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a list of common verb + adverb combinations alongside strong verb alternatives. Create sample paragraphs using weak verbs + adverbs for the child to revise.

slides.text: Adverbs are powerful tools. 'The knight walked bravely into the castle' is much better than 'The knight walked into the castle.' The adverb 'bravely' tells us HOW he walked and shows his character. Good writers use adverbs to paint precise pictures.

BUT here is a writer's secret: sometimes a STRONG VERB is even better than a weak verb + adverb. Compare: 'He walked slowly' vs. 'He crept.' 'She ate quickly' vs. 'She gobbled.' 'He said loudly' vs. 'He shouted.' The strong verb does the work of two words in just one!

So when should you use each? Use ADVERBS when the manner is unusual or surprising: 'The giant spoke gently.' (Surprising — giants are usually loud!) Use STRONG VERBS when a single word captures the feeling: 'She dashed across the playground.' Both are good tools — great writers use both.

slides.prompt: Revise these sentences two ways — once with an adverb, once with a strong verb: 1) 'He went to school.' 2) 'She looked at the painting.' 3) 'The dog ate his food.' 4) 'The wind moved the trees.' Then write a paragraph (5-6 sentences) about a dragon flying over a medieval castle. Use at least 3 adverbs AND 3 strong verbs. Underline the adverbs and circle the strong verbs.

slides.text: Your writer's toolbox now has two powerful tools: adverbs for adding detail and strong verbs for packing meaning into a single word. The best writers mix both. As you read books this week, notice when authors use adverbs and when they use strong verbs. You will start seeing choices that other readers miss!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child use adverbs effectively, identify when a strong verb is more powerful than verb + adverb, and apply both techniques in writing?

parent_notes: This lesson introduces an important writing principle: show, do not tell. Strong verbs 'show' while weak verb + adverb combinations 'tell.' However, at this age, we want to encourage BOTH techniques — not discourage adverbs. The goal is awareness that writers have choices. When reading together, occasionally point out a strong verb: 'Instead of walked slowly, the author wrote crept. Can you feel the difference?' This develops the child's ear for good writing. The dragon paragraph connects to the medieval theme.

title: Division with Remainders — What Is Left Over?
description: Students encounter division problems that do not divide evenly, discovering remainders. They use concrete objects to physically share with leftovers and learn to express the remainder in notation (13 / 4 = 3 R1).
instructions:
1. Review equal sharing/division.
2. Present: 13 cookies shared among 4 friends.
3. The child deals out beads: 3 each with 1 left over.
4. Introduce the concept: the leftover is called a REMAINDER.
5. Write: 13 / 4 = 3 R1 (3 with remainder 1).
6. Practice with multiple problems.
7. Discuss: the remainder is always LESS than the divisor.

slides.heading: Division with Remainders
slides.subheading: When Sharing Is Not Perfectly Even

items: Counters, beads, or small objects (at least 30)
Small bowls or plates (4-6) for grouping
slides.setup_instructions: Have plenty of counters and bowls ready. Prepare problems that have remainders of 1, 2, and 3. Begin with simple, relatable scenarios (sharing cookies, distributing cards).

slides.text: So far, our division problems have divided perfectly evenly. But what happens when they do NOT? Let us share 13 cookies among 4 friends. Deal them out: 1 each, 2 each, 3 each... now there is 1 cookie left, but you cannot split it into 4 equal pieces (not yet — we will learn that with fractions later!).

The 1 leftover cookie is called a REMAINDER — what REMAINS after sharing as equally as possible. We write: 13 ÷ 4 = 3 R1. This means: each person gets 3, with 1 remaining. The remainder is always LESS than the divisor (the number of groups). If the remainder were 4 or more, you could give out another round!

Try 17 ÷ 5. Deal 17 beads into 5 bowls: 3 each (that uses 15) with 2 left over. 17 ÷ 5 = 3 R2. Try 22 ÷ 3. 7 each (uses 21) with 1 left over. 22 ÷ 3 = 7 R1. Check: (3 x 7) + 1 = 22. The check formula: (divisor x quotient) + remainder = dividend.

slides.prompt: Solve with counters and record: 1) 14 ÷ 3, 2) 19 ÷ 4, 3) 23 ÷ 5, 4) 17 ÷ 6, 5) 25 ÷ 4, 6) 20 ÷ 3. Write each answer with its remainder. Then CHECK each answer using: (divisor x quotient) + remainder = dividend. Write 2 real-world remainder problems. Example: '7 children want to share 20 grapes equally. How many does each get, and how many are left over?'

slides.text: In real life, division does not always come out evenly — remainders happen all the time! When you share 7 stickers among 3 friends, each gets 2 with 1 remaining. The remainder rule: it is ALWAYS less than what you are dividing by. Later, you will learn to express remainders as fractions (that 1 leftover cookie is 1/4 of a cookie each!).
slides.mastery_check: Can the child solve division problems with remainders, express the answer in R notation, and check answers using the formula?

parent_notes: Remainders are a common source of confusion, but the concrete approach (physically dealing out objects) makes them intuitive. The key rule — remainder is always less than the divisor — is a powerful self-checking tool. The connection to fractions (1 R1 divided among 4 means each gets 1/4 more) previews upcoming work but should not be pushed yet. Real-world remainder situations arise constantly: distributing snacks among children, splitting game turns, sharing craft supplies. Use these moments to reinforce the concept naturally.

title: The Middle Ages — Medieval Towns and Guilds
description: Students learn about the growth of medieval towns and the guild system. As trade revived after the early Middle Ages, towns grew around markets and crossroads. Guilds — associations of craftspeople — regulated quality, training, and prices.
instructions:
1. Explain how towns grew: markets, trade routes, crossroads.
2. Describe medieval town life: crowded, noisy, busy markets.
3. Introduce guilds: associations of craftspeople (bakers, weavers, blacksmiths).
4. Explain the guild training system: apprentice, journeyman, master.
5. Connect to Montessori: the guild system was an education system!
6. Discuss how guilds maintained quality and fairness.
7. The child chooses a medieval craft and writes about their guild apprenticeship.
materials_needed: Images of medieval towns and markets

slides.heading: Medieval Towns and Guilds
slides.subheading: Crafts, Trade, and the Birth of the Middle Class

items: Images of medieval town markets and craftspeople
Images of guild signs and symbols
slides.setup_instructions: Display images of medieval town life: bustling markets, craftspeople at work, narrow streets. Prepare guild examples: bakers, weavers, blacksmiths, stonemasons, goldsmiths. Have the timeline ready to show when towns began growing (around 1000 AD).

slides.text: After the fall of Rome, most people lived in the countryside on feudal estates. But slowly, TOWNS began to grow — at crossroads where traders met, near rivers for transportation, and around castles for protection. By 1000 AD, towns were booming centers of trade and craftsmanship.

Medieval towns were crowded, noisy, and exciting! Narrow streets were lined with shops where craftspeople worked in the open air so customers could watch. The MARKET SQUARE was the heart of every town — here farmers sold food, merchants traded goods from faraway lands, and townspeople gathered for news and entertainment.

Craftspeople organized themselves into GUILDS — associations of people in the same trade. There were guilds for bakers, weavers, blacksmiths, carpenters, stonemasons, and many more. Guilds set quality standards (no selling bad bread!), controlled prices, and took care of members who got sick or injured.

The guild training system was brilliant! At age 7-12, a child became an APPRENTICE, living with a master craftsperson and learning the trade for 7 years. Then they became a JOURNEYMAN, traveling to different towns to learn from other masters. Finally, they created a 'masterpiece' — their best work — and if the guild approved, they became a MASTER. Sound familiar? It is like the Montessori journey of learning!

slides.prompt: Choose a medieval craft: baker, blacksmith, weaver, stonemason, or goldsmith. In your history journal, write a first-person account of your life as an apprentice in that guild. Describe: What is your master like? What are you learning? What is a typical day? What is your dream masterpiece? Include at least 5 details about your craft. Draw yourself at work!

slides.text: Guilds created the first 'middle class' — people who were neither nobles nor peasants but skilled workers who earned good livings. The guild training system — apprentice, journeyman, master — influenced education for centuries. Even today, many trades use apprenticeship. The medieval town was where modern business and education were born!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain how medieval towns grew, describe the guild system, and trace the path from apprentice to master?

parent_notes: Medieval guilds are fascinating and directly parallel to Montessori's learning philosophy: hands-on training, progressing through stages of mastery, and being mentored by experts. The apprentice-journeyman-master progression resonates with children — they are apprentices in many skills! The creative writing exercise (first-person apprentice account) builds empathy and historical imagination. If your child is interested in a particular craft, explore further: how blacksmiths forged swords, how weavers made cloth, or how bakers made bread (connecting to our cooking lesson!).

title: South America — The Andes Mountains and Inca Civilization
description: Students explore the Andes Mountains in depth, learning about their formation, extreme altitude, and the remarkable Inca civilization that thrived in these mountains. They study Machu Picchu, Inca roads, and terrace farming.
instructions:
1. Locate the Andes on the map — running the full western edge.
2. Review tectonic plate formation of the Andes.
3. Introduce the Inca Empire: the largest in pre-Columbian Americas.
4. Describe Inca achievements: roads, bridges, terrace farming, Machu Picchu.
5. Discuss how the Incas adapted to extreme altitude.
6. The child creates a poster about the Inca civilization.
7. Record in geography journal.
materials_needed: Images of Machu Picchu and Inca roads

items: Map of South America with Andes highlighted
Images of Machu Picchu, Inca roads, terrace farming, and Inca artifacts
slides.setup_instructions: Display dramatic images of the Andes and Machu Picchu. Have the map visible. Prepare facts about the Inca Empire for reference.

slides.text: The Andes Mountains are the LONGEST mountain range on any continent — 4,500 miles along South America's western coast, passing through 7 countries! They formed when the oceanic Nazca Plate dove under the South American Plate, pushing up massive peaks. Some are over 22,000 feet high — so high that there is less oxygen and the air is freezing!

In these impossibly high mountains, the INCA EMPIRE flourished from the 1400s until the 1530s. The Incas built the largest empire in pre-Columbian Americas, stretching from Ecuador to Chile. And they did it WITHOUT a written language, WITHOUT the wheel, and WITHOUT iron tools! They used runners on roads, knot-strings (quipu) for records, and stone tools.

Inca achievements were remarkable. They built 25,000 miles of ROADS through the mountains (more than the Roman Empire!), including rope bridges over gorges. They invented TERRACE FARMING — cutting flat steps into mountainsides to grow crops at extreme altitude. And they built MACHU PICCHU — a city in the clouds at 8,000 feet, so perfectly built that stones fit together without mortar!

slides.prompt: Create an 'Amazing Incas' poster or journal page. Include: a map showing the Inca Empire along the Andes, a drawing of Machu Picchu's terraces, and at least 5 fascinating facts about Inca civilization. Answer these questions in writing: How did the Incas solve the problem of farming on steep mountains? Why is Machu Picchu considered one of the world's greatest architectural achievements?

slides.text: The Inca civilization proves that geography does not limit human creativity — it inspires it! The Andes are harsh and extreme, yet the Incas built one of history's greatest empires there. Their terrace farming, road building, and architecture rival anything from the ancient world. Machu Picchu reminds us that human ingenuity can achieve the seemingly impossible.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child describe 3 Inca achievements, explain how terrace farming works, and explain why Machu Picchu is significant?

parent_notes: The Inca civilization connects geography, history, engineering, and agriculture beautifully. The key concept is adaptation — the Incas adapted brilliantly to one of the harshest environments on Earth. Terrace farming is a particularly accessible concept; if you have a hillside, you can demonstrate the principle with a small dirt mound and water. Machu Picchu images are dramatic and inspiring. If your child is curious about the Spanish conquest that ended the Inca Empire, address it honestly but age-appropriately — it is an important part of the story that connects to the Age of Exploration (upcoming).

title: Read Aloud — Ramona Quimby, Age 8, Chapters 4-6
description: Continue reading Ramona Quimby as she deals with embarrassing moments at school and tension at home. Students discuss empathy, humor in difficult situations, and how authors create characters that feel real.
instructions:
1. Review chapters 1-3.
2. Read chapters 4-6 aloud.
3. Discuss Ramona's embarrassing moments — have you had similar experiences?
4. Notice Cleary's humor: how does she make embarrassment funny?
5. Discuss family dynamics: Ramona's relationship with Beezus.
6. Identify compound sentences in Cleary's writing.
7. The child writes about an embarrassing moment of their own, using humor.
materials_needed: Ramona Quimby, Age 8 by Beverly Cleary

slides.heading: Ramona Quimby, Age 8
slides.subheading: Chapters 4-6: The Hard-Boiled Egg and Other Disasters

items: Ramona Quimby, Age 8 by Beverly Cleary
slides.setup_instructions: Review what has happened so far. These chapters include some of Ramona's most famous embarrassing moments. Read with empathy and humor — the reader should feel both sorry for Ramona and amused by her situations.

slides.text: Ramona is having one of those weeks where EVERYTHING goes wrong. As we read, notice how Beverly Cleary handles embarrassment. She does not make fun of Ramona — she makes us UNDERSTAND how Ramona feels while also seeing the humor in the situation. That is a very special kind of writing.

Pay attention to the relationship between Ramona and her older sister Beezus. Siblings can drive each other crazy BUT also love each other deeply. Cleary shows both sides. Do you have a sibling? Does this feel familiar?

As a writer, notice how Cleary uses COMPOUND SENTENCES to show Ramona's thoughts: 'She wanted to be good, BUT things kept going wrong.' The 'but' shows the conflict between what Ramona wants and what actually happens — that tension is what makes the story compelling.

slides.prompt: Write about an embarrassing or frustrating moment from YOUR life — but write it like Beverly Cleary would: with empathy AND humor. Start with the situation, describe how you felt using adjectives and adverbs, tell what happened, and find something funny about it (even if it was not funny at the time). Use at least 2 compound sentences with 'but.' Aim for 1 full page.

slides.text: Beverly Cleary shows us that embarrassing moments are UNIVERSAL — everyone has them, even adults. By writing about them with humor and kindness, she helps readers feel less alone. Your embarrassing moment story does the same thing — it tells someone else 'you are not the only one!' That is the gift of writing.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify how Cleary uses humor and empathy together, and write about a personal experience with both honesty and humor?

parent_notes: Ramona's embarrassing moments are some of the most beloved scenes in children's literature. The egg-on-the-head scene (if in these chapters) is legendary. Cleary's genius is treating children's feelings as real and important while finding gentle humor in their situations. The writing exercise (describing your own embarrassing moment with humor) is therapeutic — it reframes difficult experiences as stories that connect us. If your child is reluctant to share embarrassing moments, model by sharing one of your own first.

title: Poetry Writing — Similes and Metaphors
description: Students learn about similes (comparisons using like or as) and metaphors (direct comparisons) as poetic devices. They find examples in poems, create their own similes and metaphors, and write a poem rich with figurative language.
instructions:
1. Review poetry elements from last week.
2. Introduce similes: 'The moon was like a silver coin.'
3. Introduce metaphors: 'The moon was a silver coin.'
4. Find similes and metaphors in published poems.
5. Practice creating similes for common objects.
6. Practice creating metaphors.
7. Write a poem using at least 3 similes or metaphors.

items: Poetry anthology with examples of similes and metaphors
Figurative language reference chart (simile: uses like/as; metaphor: direct comparison)
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare examples of similes and metaphors from published poems. Create a T-chart: Simile (uses like/as) vs. Metaphor (IS the thing). Have several objects ready for practice comparisons.

slides.text: Poets are magicians with words. One of their best tricks is COMPARISON. A SIMILE compares two different things using 'like' or 'as': 'Her smile was LIKE sunshine.' 'The ice was AS smooth AS glass.' You can spot similes because they always use 'like' or 'as.'

A METAPHOR goes further — it says something IS something else: 'Her smile WAS sunshine.' 'The ice WAS a mirror.' No 'like' or 'as' — the comparison is direct. Both create vivid pictures, but metaphors are stronger because they say the thing literally IS the other thing.

Let us practice! The sky at sunset... Simile: 'The sky was like a painting.' Metaphor: 'The sky was a painting.' Your hair after swimming... Simile: 'My hair looked like a bird's nest.' Metaphor: 'My hair was a tangled jungle.' The comparison should surprise the reader and make them see something in a new way!

slides.prompt: Create similes and metaphors for these: 1) The stars at night (simile AND metaphor), 2) A thunderstorm (simile AND metaphor), 3) Your best friend's laugh (simile AND metaphor). Then write a poem of at least 8 lines that includes at least 2 similes and 1 metaphor. Topic ideas: a season, a storm, the ocean, a person you love, or a dream. Label each simile (S) and metaphor (M) in the margin.

slides.text: Similes and metaphors transform ordinary words into extraordinary images. When you write 'the sun was a golden eye watching over the world,' you create a picture that a literal description never could. These tools belong to poets, but ALL great writers use them. Start noticing similes and metaphors everywhere — in books, songs, and everyday speech!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child distinguish between similes and metaphors, create original examples of each, and incorporate them into a poem?

parent_notes: Similes and metaphors are stepping stones to understanding figurative language, which is essential for reading comprehension at higher levels. Children at this age naturally create wonderful comparisons ('the caterpillar moved like a tiny wave'). Encourage creativity over correctness. Common similes in everyday speech ('busy as a bee,' 'cold as ice') are great starting points, but original comparisons are more valuable. When reading together, point out similes and metaphors: 'Did you catch that comparison? What two things is the author connecting?'

title: Fractions — Adding Like Fractions with Fraction Circles
description: Students learn to add fractions with the same denominator using fraction circle insets. They physically combine fraction pieces to find sums and record the addition equations, discovering the rule: keep the denominator, add the numerators.
instructions:
1. Review fraction circle basics.
2. Present: 1/4 + 2/4. Place 1 fourth-piece and 2 fourth-pieces together.
3. Count: 3 fourth-pieces = 3/4.
4. State the rule: keep the denominator, add the numerators.
5. Practice with various denominators.
6. Introduce sums that equal 1 whole: 2/3 + 1/3 = 3/3 = 1.
7. Solve fraction addition word problems.

items: Montessori fraction circle insets (halves through tenths)
Colored pencils matching fraction circle colors
slides.setup_instructions: Set out fraction circle insets. Prepare addition problems with like denominators, including some that sum to 1 whole. Open math journal to a page titled 'Adding Fractions.'

slides.text: Adding fractions is simpler than you might think! Let us start: 1/4 + 2/4. Take 1 fourth-piece and 2 fourth-pieces. Put them together in the circle frame. How many fourth-pieces do you have? 3! So 1/4 + 2/4 = 3/4. We added the TOP numbers (1 + 2 = 3) and kept the BOTTOM number (4).

The rule: when adding fractions with the SAME denominator, ADD the numerators and KEEP the denominator. Why? Because the pieces are the same SIZE. Adding 1 fourth-piece + 2 fourth-pieces is like adding 1 apple + 2 apples = 3 apples. The 'kind' of piece stays the same!

What happens when fractions add up to a WHOLE? 2/3 + 1/3. Place 2 third-pieces and 1 third-piece in the frame. They fill the entire circle! 2/3 + 1/3 = 3/3 = 1 whole! Any fraction where the numerator equals the denominator equals 1: 2/2, 3/3, 4/4, 5/5 — all equal 1.

Word problem: 'You ate 1/6 of the pizza for lunch and 2/6 for dinner. How much pizza did you eat in total?' 1/6 + 2/6 = 3/6. You ate 3/6 (or one-half!) of the pizza. Fraction addition answers real questions about parts of things!

slides.prompt: Solve with fraction circles and record: 1) 1/3 + 1/3, 2) 2/5 + 1/5, 3) 3/8 + 2/8, 4) 1/4 + 3/4 (what happens?), 5) 2/6 + 3/6 + 1/6 (three fractions!). Draw the circles for each problem showing the pieces. Write 2 word problems involving adding fractions with the same denominator. Circle any answer that equals 1 whole.

slides.text: Adding fractions with the same denominator is just like adding anything else — 2 thirds + 1 third = 3 thirds, just like 2 cats + 1 cat = 3 cats! The denominator names the pieces, and the numerator counts them. Simple and logical! Next, we will tackle subtracting fractions.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child add fractions with like denominators using the circles, state the rule, and solve fraction addition word problems?

parent_notes: Fraction addition with like denominators is straightforward once children understand what fractions mean. The concrete experience of combining pieces in the circle frame makes the rule obvious: you are just counting how many pieces of the same size you have. The moment when fractions add to 1 whole (3/3 = 1) is an important insight. Do NOT introduce unlike denominator addition yet — that requires finding common denominators, which is an upper elementary skill. Keep it concrete and fun!

title: Engineering Design Challenge — Build a Bridge
description: Students apply their knowledge of simple machines and structures to an engineering design challenge: build a bridge from limited materials that can hold the most weight. They follow the engineering design process: ask, imagine, plan, create, test, improve.
instructions:
1. Present the challenge: build a bridge that spans 12 inches and holds weight.
2. Introduce the engineering design process: ask, imagine, plan, create, test, improve.
3. Provide limited materials: popsicle sticks, straws, tape, paper.
4. The child brainstorms and sketches designs.
5. Build the bridge.
6. Test by placing weights (coins, small objects) until it collapses.
7. Analyze: What worked? What failed? How could you improve?
8. Rebuild and retest (if time allows).

items: 2 equal stacks of books (12 inches apart) as supports
Small weights for testing: coins, washers, or small toys
Science journal and pencil for design sketches
slides.setup_instructions: Set up the bridge supports: two equal stacks of books exactly 12 inches apart. Lay out building materials. Have weights ready for testing. Emphasize that materials are LIMITED — the child must plan carefully.

slides.text: CHALLENGE: Build a bridge that spans the 12-inch gap between these book stacks and holds as much weight as possible. You can ONLY use the materials provided: 20 popsicle sticks, 10 straws, 2 feet of tape, and 2 sheets of paper. This is real engineering!

Engineers follow a DESIGN PROCESS. Step 1: ASK — What is the problem? (Bridge a 12-inch gap, hold maximum weight.) Step 2: IMAGINE — What are possible solutions? Step 3: PLAN — Sketch your best design. Step 4: CREATE — Build it! Step 5: TEST — Does it work? Step 6: IMPROVE — Make it better!

Engineering tips: TRIANGLES are the strongest shape in engineering (they do not collapse like rectangles). LAYERS add strength (a folded paper is stronger than flat). DISTRIBUTION matters — spread the weight across the bridge, do not pile it in one spot. Think about the simple machines you know: where do you see inclined planes, levers, or wedge shapes?

slides.prompt: Follow the design process: 1) Sketch 2-3 possible bridge designs (5 minutes). 2) Choose your best design and BUILD it (15 minutes). 3) TEST: place weights one at a time. Record how much weight the bridge holds before it fails. 4) ANALYZE: Why did it fail? Draw the failure point. 5) If time allows, IMPROVE and retest! Record everything in your science journal.

slides.text: Engineering is about solving problems through design, testing, and improvement. Your first design probably was not perfect — and that is how engineering works! Real engineers test and improve dozens of times before a product is ready. The design process (ask, imagine, plan, create, test, improve) applies to ANY problem, not just bridges. You are thinking like an engineer!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child follow the engineering design process, build a functional bridge from limited materials, and analyze what worked and what could be improved?

parent_notes: The bridge challenge is a highlight of the science curriculum — it integrates physics, engineering, creativity, and problem-solving. Resist the urge to help with the design; let the child struggle and figure it out. Failure is essential to the process! When the bridge collapses, ask: 'What happened? Where did it break? What could you change?' This develops resilience and analytical thinking. Celebrate the process, not just the result. If your child loves this, similar challenges (tower-building, egg drop, boat design) can be done with household materials.

title: Watercolor Landscapes — Painting a Medieval Scene
description: Students learn basic watercolor techniques (wet-on-wet, wet-on-dry, washes) and paint a medieval landscape featuring a castle, rolling hills, and sky. They apply knowledge of color mixing, layering, and creating depth.
instructions:
1. Introduce watercolor as a painting medium: transparent, fluid, luminous.
2. Demonstrate techniques: flat wash (sky), wet-on-wet (soft clouds), wet-on-dry (details).
3. Practice each technique on scrap paper.
4. Sketch a light pencil outline of a medieval landscape.
5. Paint the sky first (lightest area), let it dry.
6. Paint the background hills (lighter), then foreground (darker).
7. Add details: castle, trees, path.
8. Let dry completely.

items: Watercolor paper (heavier weight is better — 140 lb if available)
Plate or palette for mixing colors
slides.setup_instructions: Cover the work surface. Tape the watercolor paper to the surface to prevent curling. Fill the water container. Set out paints and mixing palette. Have paper towels and scrap paper ready for practice. Demonstrate techniques before the child paints their final piece.

slides.text: Watercolor is a beautiful painting medium — the colors are transparent, which means they glow with light! The key to watercolor is WATER CONTROL. More water = lighter, more transparent color. Less water = darker, more intense color. We will learn three techniques today.

Technique 1: FLAT WASH. Wet the paper with clean water, then apply diluted paint in smooth strokes — perfect for skies. Technique 2: WET-ON-WET. Drop paint onto wet paper and watch it bloom and blend — creates soft clouds and misty effects. Technique 3: WET-ON-DRY. Paint on dry paper for sharp, detailed edges — good for buildings and trees.

For our medieval landscape, work from BACK TO FRONT and LIGHT TO DARK. Start with the sky (lightest). Let it dry. Paint distant hills (lighter green or blue-green). Let it dry. Paint closer hills (darker green). Finally, add the castle and foreground details. Each layer should be dry before adding the next!

slides.prompt: First, practice the three techniques on scrap paper. Then lightly sketch your medieval landscape: sky, distant hills, closer hills, a castle, and some foreground elements (path, trees, field). Paint in layers: 1) Sky wash, 2) Distant hills, 3) Middle ground with castle, 4) Foreground details. Let each layer dry before adding the next. Remember: light to dark, back to front!

slides.text: Watercolor painting teaches patience (waiting for layers to dry), planning (working back to front), and the beauty of letting colors flow. Medieval artists did not use watercolors much — they used tempera and egg-based paints — but landscape painting has been beloved for centuries. Your painting captures a world that existed 800 years ago, brought to life through your artistic vision!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child demonstrate flat wash, wet-on-wet, and wet-on-dry techniques, and paint a layered landscape with foreground and background?

parent_notes: Watercolor painting develops patience (waiting for layers to dry is essential), planning, and color sense. The most common mistake is using too little water or not waiting between layers. Watercolor paper makes a huge difference — if you only have thin paper, use less water. The medieval landscape connects to the history study of castles. If the first painting is not satisfying, try again — watercolor skills improve dramatically with practice. Display the finished painting; even imperfect watercolors have a beautiful, luminous quality.

title: Hand Sewing Project — Making a Simple Pouch
description: Students apply their running stitch and whip stitch skills to a practical project: sewing a simple drawstring pouch from felt. They learn to plan a project, cut fabric to size, and complete a functional sewn item.
instructions:
1. Review running stitch and whip stitch.
2. Present the project: a drawstring pouch for small treasures.
3. Measure and cut two rectangles of felt (4 x 6 inches each).
4. Align the pieces and whip stitch three sides together (bottom and two sides).
5. Fold the top edge down and running stitch to create a channel.
6. Thread a drawstring through the channel.
7. Test the pouch with small items.
8. Decorate with embroidery if time allows.

items: 2 rectangles of felt (4 x 6 inches each, same or different colors)
12-inch string, ribbon, or yarn for drawstring
Optional: buttons, beads, or embroidery thread for decoration
slides.setup_instructions: Pre-measure and cut the felt rectangles if the child cannot cut straight. Pre-thread a needle. Have pins ready to hold pieces together. Demonstrate the folded-top channel technique before the child attempts it.

slides.text: Today you make something USEFUL — a drawstring pouch! This is a real sewing project with a real purpose. You will measure, cut, stitch, and create a functional pouch for storing small treasures. This is how people have made bags for thousands of years!

Step 1: Stack the two felt rectangles evenly. Pin them together along three sides (leave the top open — that is where you put things in!). Step 2: Whip stitch along the bottom and up both sides. Keep stitches even and not too far apart — gaps let things fall out!

Step 3: For the drawstring channel, fold the top edge of BOTH layers down about 1 inch toward the inside. Pin it. Running stitch along the bottom of the fold, leaving a small opening on each side where the drawstring will enter and exit. This creates a TUNNEL for the string to pass through.

Step 4: Thread your string or ribbon through the channel using a safety pin as a guide (pin it to the string end and push it through). Pull both ends out one side. Pull to close the pouch, release to open! Your pouch is complete! You can decorate it with embroidered initials or simple designs.

slides.prompt: Complete your drawstring pouch following the steps. Test it: put small items inside and pull the drawstring closed. Does it hold things securely? If any gaps are too large, add extra stitches. Decorate the front with your initials or a simple design using running stitch in a contrasting color. In your journal, draw your finished pouch and write what you will keep in it.

slides.text: You made something REAL and USEFUL with your own hands! The skills you used — measuring, cutting, stitching, and problem-solving — are the same skills tailors, fashion designers, and craftspeople use every day. Your drawstring pouch is a functional item made by YOU. That is something to be proud of!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child complete a functional drawstring pouch with whip stitching on three sides and a running stitch channel?

parent_notes: Completing a functional sewn item is a major accomplishment. The drawstring pouch is simple enough to finish in one session but complex enough to feel like a real achievement. If the channel for the drawstring is too difficult, simplify by just tying the top closed with string. The key is that the child creates something they actually USE — this validates the effort and motivates future sewing. Display or use the pouch proudly. Next sewing projects could include: a bookmark, a small pillow, or a felt ornament.

title: Writing Review — Editing and Revising Checklist
description: Students learn the difference between editing (fixing errors) and revising (improving content). They create a personal editing checklist and apply it to revise a piece of their own writing from earlier this week.
instructions:
1. Explain: REVISING = making writing BETTER (content, ideas, flow).
2. Explain: EDITING = making writing CORRECT (spelling, grammar, punctuation).
3. Create an editing checklist together.
4. Model revising a paragraph: add details, improve word choice.
5. Model editing: fix spelling, punctuation, capitalization.
6. The child revises and edits their personal narrative from this week.
7. Write a final clean copy.

items: Language journal with this week's personal narrative draft
Red or colored pen for editing marks
slides.setup_instructions: Have the child's personal narrative from this week's writing lesson available. Create or print an editing checklist. Prepare a sample paragraph with intentional errors and weak spots for modeling the revision and editing process.

slides.text: Good writers do not just write and stop — they REVISE and EDIT. These are two different things! REVISING means making your writing BETTER: adding details, choosing stronger words, improving the flow, making sure ideas are clear. EDITING means making it CORRECT: fixing spelling, grammar, and punctuation.

Always revise FIRST, then edit. It makes no sense to fix the spelling of a sentence you might delete! Revision questions: Is my beginning interesting? Did I include enough details? Are my sentences varied (some short, some compound)? Is my ending strong? Is anything confusing or unclear?

Editing checklist: Capital letters at the beginning of sentences? Period, question mark, or exclamation point at the end? Commas before conjunctions in compound sentences? Spelling rules applied (silent e, doubling)? Quotation marks around dialogue? Paragraphs indented?

slides.prompt: Take your personal narrative from earlier this week. First REVISE: read it aloud. Add at least 2 descriptive details (adjectives or adverbs). Replace at least 1 weak verb with a strong verb. Add at least 1 compound sentence if you do not have one. Then EDIT using the checklist: check every sentence for capitals, punctuation, and spelling. Finally, write a clean final copy with all improvements. Compare the first draft to the final — notice the improvement!

slides.text: Every published book, article, and story has been revised and edited — usually many times! Professional writers revise 5, 10, even 20 drafts before they are satisfied. Revision is not a sign of failure — it is a sign of CRAFTSMANSHIP. Your editing checklist is a tool you will use for years. The difference between a first draft and a revised final copy is the difference between good and great writing.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child distinguish between revising and editing, apply the editing checklist, and improve a piece of writing through both processes?

parent_notes: The revision/editing distinction is crucial for developing writers. Many children resist revision because they see it as criticism of their first effort. Reframe it: musicians practice, athletes train, and writers revise — it is how everyone gets better. The comparison between first and final drafts is powerful — physically place them side by side and celebrate the improvement. The editing checklist becomes a permanent tool; post it near the child's writing area. At this age, focus on 3-4 checklist items maximum — adding more as skills develop.

title: Measurement — Perimeter with Rulers
description: Students learn that perimeter is the distance around a shape. They measure the sides of rectangles, triangles, and irregular shapes with rulers and calculate the total perimeter by adding all side lengths.
instructions:
1. Introduce perimeter: the distance around the OUTSIDE of a shape.
2. Walk the 'perimeter' of the room together — the total distance around.
3. Measure the sides of a rectangle; add them for the perimeter.
4. Measure the sides of a triangle.
5. Measure an irregular shape.
6. Discover the rectangle shortcut: P = 2 x (length + width).
7. Practice with various shapes and record measurements.
materials_needed: Various flat shapes (paper rectangles, triangles, irregular shapes)

items: Pre-cut paper shapes: rectangles, squares, triangles, and irregular shapes
slides.setup_instructions: Cut several flat shapes from cardstock: 2 rectangles of different sizes, 1 square, 1 triangle, and 1 irregular shape. Do not label the measurements — the child will measure each side.

slides.text: PERIMETER is the total distance AROUND the outside of a shape. Imagine an ant walking around the edge of a rectangle — the distance the ant walks is the perimeter! The word comes from Greek: 'peri' means around, 'meter' means measure. Perimeter = measure around.

To find the perimeter, measure EVERY side and ADD them up. This rectangle has 4 sides: measure the top (6 inches), the right side (4 inches), the bottom (6 inches), the left side (4 inches). Perimeter = 6 + 4 + 6 + 4 = 20 inches. Notice that opposite sides of a rectangle are equal!

Since rectangles have 2 pairs of equal sides, there is a shortcut: Perimeter = 2 x (length + width). For our rectangle: 2 x (6 + 4) = 2 x 10 = 20 inches. Same answer, faster math! A SQUARE is even simpler: all 4 sides are equal, so P = 4 x side. A 5-inch square has P = 4 x 5 = 20 inches.

slides.prompt: Measure and calculate the perimeter of each shape: 1) Rectangle A, 2) Rectangle B, 3) The square, 4) The triangle, 5) The irregular shape. For each: measure all sides in centimeters, show your addition, and write the total perimeter. Use the rectangle shortcut for the rectangles and check with addition. Draw each shape in your journal with side measurements labeled. Answer: If you have 24 inches of ribbon, can you outline each shape? Which ones fit?

slides.text: Perimeter is used everywhere! Fencing a yard, framing a picture, wrapping a gift, outlining a garden bed — anytime you need to know the distance around something, you need perimeter. Remember: measure every side and add them up. For rectangles, use the shortcut: P = 2 x (length + width).
slides.mastery_check: Can the child measure all sides of a shape, calculate the perimeter by addition, and use the rectangle perimeter shortcut?

parent_notes: Perimeter is a practical and approachable geometry concept. The 'ant walking around the edge' visualization helps children understand what perimeter means. Real-world applications abound: measure the perimeter of their desk, their bedroom, a book, or a picture frame. The rectangle shortcut (P = 2(l + w)) introduces parentheses and the distributive property informally. For an extension, give the child a fixed perimeter (24 inches of string) and challenge them to make different rectangles — this builds area intuition naturally.

title: The Middle Ages — The Cathedral Builders
description: Students learn about medieval cathedrals as extraordinary feats of architecture and faith. They study Gothic architecture features: pointed arches, flying buttresses, stained glass windows, and ribbed vaults, understanding how these innovations allowed taller, lighter buildings filled with light.
instructions:
1. Show images of medieval cathedrals (Notre-Dame, Chartres, Canterbury).
2. Explain: cathedrals took 50-200 years to build!
3. Describe Gothic architecture: pointed arches support more weight.
4. Explain flying buttresses: external supports that let walls be thinner.
5. Discuss stained glass windows: teaching Bible stories to people who could not read.
6. The child designs a stained glass window on paper.
7. Record in history journal.

slides.heading: Cathedral Builders
slides.subheading: Gothic Architecture and the Race to the Sky

items: Photographs of medieval cathedrals: Notre-Dame de Paris, Chartres, Canterbury, Cologne
Black construction paper (for stained glass frame)
Tissue paper in various colors (for stained glass)
